Title: üñº In Yekaterinburg, a 16-year-old girl was forcibly married off....
Description: In Yekaterinburg, a 16-year-old girl was forcibly married off. Sledkom became interested in the caseAfter information spread in local public pages that a 16-year-old girl was forcibly married by her parents to a 24-year-old man, the head of the Investigative Committee of Russia, Alexander Bastrykin, ordered to open a criminal case on the fact of forced marriage and restriction of freedom of a minor. This was reported by the department's press service. The incident occurred in February 2024. The girl refused to marry by consent, after which her parents, belonging to the Yazidi community, allegedly beat her and forcibly took her to the groom's house, where she was deprived of freedom, the opportunity to study and communicate with relatives and friends. The marriage was concluded only according to tradition, but not in the registry office.Girl's friends toldE1 that she was under constant control in her husband's house, she was forbidden to continue her studies, her phone was monitored and she was forbidden to leave the house. Five years ago, the groom's family already a tragedy occurred: the man's younger sister committed suicide at the age of 16 when they tried to marry her off to a 50-year-old man. The girl's relatives claim that she was happy in her marriage, calling the accusations -slander.- The head of the public organization -Yazidis of the Urals,- Georgy Asoev, said that the couple lives in peace and harmony, and called the complaints -nonsense.- He emphasized that in the 21st century, forced marriage is impossible, and called not to interfere in family affairs. Nurzida Bensgier, director of the Interethnic Information Center in Yekaterinburg, also commented on the situation. She noted that in diasporas outside their country, the desire to preserve national identity, faith and traditions is especially pronounced, especially in matters of marriage and funerals. According to a study by the human rights organization Ad Rem published in 2024, 4,453 marriages involving underage girls were registered in the country in 2021 alone. However, official statistics do not reflect the real scale of the problem, since many such unions are not officially registered.Yazidis are an ethno-confessional group of Kurds living mainly in northwestern Iraq, northern and northeastern Syria. In Russia, according to the 2010 census, there are more than 40 thousand of them.

Having concluded a purchase and sale agreement, he transferred the old house into the ownership of the city and went to war. This disagreement led to a legal conflict, as a result of which the certificate for new housing was canceled.The head of Orsk, Artem Vorobyov, responded to the video message on his Telegram channel, noting that such cases after a flood are not uncommon and are usually resolved in court. He assured that, together with the prosecutor‚Äôs office and the regional Ministry of Construction, all possible measures are being taken to restore Alexander‚Äôs rights. -It cannot be otherwise,- Vorobiev emphasized. Chairman of the Investigative Committee Alexander Bastrykin instructed the regional department of the Investigative Committee to conduct an investigation into this fact and provide a report on the activities carried out.Soon Vorobiev recorded another video message, saying that he had found a solution to safely resolve the situation, but did not provide details.At the same time, the problems of other residents of Orsk, left without housing, remain unresolved.April 8 2024, more than a hundred residents of Orsk came out to a rally to the local administration building, protesting against insufficient compensation and the inaction of the authorities. The protesters demanded a review of the terms of payments and acceleration of the process of providing assistance. In response to this, the governor of the Orenburg region, Denis Pasler, promised to double regional payments.At the end of May 2024, residents of Orsk also claimed that they did not receive compensation. Title: üñº After returning from the war in Ukraine, veterans killed at le...
Description: After returning from the war in Ukraine, -veterans- killed at least 240 people in Russian regionsOn the third anniversary of Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion of Ukraine, journalists from the publication -7x7- conducted an analysis of judicial statistics and establishedthat combatants returning from the front were involved in the murder of at least 240 people in various regions of the Russian Federation. The study covers sentences under five articles of the Criminal Code related to murder handed down between 2022 and 2025. However, given that some cases are still pending and detailed data is not available for a number of convictions, the actual number of victims may be higher. According to the study, Russian courts handed down 225 verdicts in cases of murders committed by former combatants in Ukraine. The geography of crimes covers 62 regions of the country. The largest number of victims was recorded in the Krasnodar Territory and the Kostroma Region - 14 people in each region. In the Rostov region, 12 people died at the hands of those returning from the war, in the Trans-Baikal Territory - 10, in the Krasnoyarsk Territory - 9. In the Volgograd and Perm regions, 8 victims were registered each. The victims of these crimes are not only relatives or acquaintances of former military personnel, but also random people: children, pensioners, passers-by. In some cases, the defendants are charged with additional charges related to rape and robbery. Courts often consider participation in hostilities on the territory of Ukraine as a mitigating circumstance, and awards and certificates received at the front as a positive characteristic of the defendant‚Äôs personality.

Title: üñº Since the start of the war in Russia, the number of political ...
Description: Since the start of the war in Russia, the number of political persecutions has almost doubled - report Avtozak LiveFrom 2022 to 2024, the number of political persecutions in Russia almost doubled - from 1265 to 2373 cases. At the same time, the average time for consideration of politically motivated cases has also decreased significantly, the Avtozak Live team found out.According to their data, from February 24, 2022 to February 9, 2025, more than 5,400 politically motivated criminal cases were initiated under 146 articles of the criminal code against 5,254 people, at least 2,940 of whom are now in custody. In more than 1,900 cases, cases against the persecuted were initiated under two or more articles. The most charges - 16 - were brought against Andrei Pronsky, who is accused of preparing an attempt on the life of Vladimir Solovyov. The remaining nine defendants in this case are charged with 15 articles each.One of the most common articles for political persecution in Russia is Article 205 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation (-Terrorist Act-). According to it, people are regularly imprisoned for arson of military registration and enlistment offices and other damage to military infrastructure. Also, this article often prosecutes victims of telephone scammers who convince people to participate in arson.The number of criminal cases against minors increased significantly with the start of the war. In 2024, 177 cases were opened, mainly on charges of preparing terrorist acts, sabotage and rehabilitation of Nazism. The youngest accused was a 14-year-old girl who fried sausages on the Eternal Flame in Ruza.Avtozak Live notes that with the beginning of the invasion of Ukraine repressions became more brutal and widespread.

Description: A measles outbreak in Texas and New Mexico amid the growing popularity of the anti-vaccination movement - almost 100 cases90 cases of infection have been confirmed in Texas, nine in New Mexico. The highest number of cases is in Gaines County, where the vaccination rate is below the state average.The outbreak began in the South Plains region of Texas in late January, the state Department of Health Services said. According to the latest data, among the 90 cases, 77 are children. 16 people are hospitalized.In New Mexico, infections were reported in Lee County, which borders the epicenter of the outbreak in Texas, the local Department of Health said. Nine people fell ill there, including four children.Local services are urgently setting up additional vaccination and testing points to contain the spread of infection. Free vaccinations are available in Seminole (Gaines County, Texas) and Lee County (New Mexico). Additional testing sites have also opened in these areas.Measles is considered one of the most contagious infections, and outbreaks occur when herd immunity levels fall below 95%. In Gaines County, the rate is significantly lower: last year, only 82% of children received the two required doses of the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine.Vaccine refusal rates are on the rise in the region. In Texas, the law allows for -conscientious objection- to vaccinate a child, and in Gaines County, 13% of students exercised this right.The situation is complicated by the appointment of Robert Kennedy Jr. as Secretary of Health. Kennedy is known to be skeptical of vaccines and cited controversial studies about their possible side effects. He has already stated that he intends to review the childhood vaccination system.In the United States, measles was officially considered eliminated, but due to a decrease in the level of vaccination, cases of the disease are being recorded more and more often. In 2024, the country reported 285 cases of measles in more than 30 states.

Title: In the Kirov region, a cleaner was convicted for commenting about...
Description: In the Kirov region, a cleaner was convicted for commenting about a deceased participant in the war in UkraineThe Kirov regional court sentenced the cleaner Raisa Novoselova, convicting her for insulting the memory of defenders of the Fatherland (Part 4 of Article 354.1 of the Criminal Code), writes the SOVA research center. The woman received a six-month suspended sentence and a ban on publishing materials on the Internet for a year. The verdict was handed down on January 15, 2025.The reason for the criminal prosecution was a comment published by Novoselova under a post about a serviceman who died in the war in Ukraine. -The comment contained linguistic and psychological signs of humiliation of the soldiers of the Russian Armed Forces who died during a special military operation,- says the published decision of the court.Novoselova admitted her guilt and asked to consider the case in a special manner without examining the evidence. The case was opened in October 2024, after the regional department of the Investigative Committee reported the publication of a comment that, in their opinion, expressed disrespect and insult to the fallen defenders of the Fatherland. The SOVA Research Center considered the actions of law enforcement agencies unnecessary, noting that the relatives of the deceased could have filed a civil lawsuit to protect their honor and dignity, rather than resort to criminal prosecution.

With the start of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, Rudneva became one of the public representatives of the anti-war movement.The Swedish Security Service considered that Rudneva's research could allegedly benefit the Russian military or related organizations. As a result, she may be banned from entering Sweden and the Schengen countries for 20 years.Rudneva denies the charges.-This is very unfair. My work is related to theoretical mathematics, which has no military application,- she said in an interview with Sveriges Radio.The girl previously worked at Skoltech, which is under US and EU sanctions and, according to the US, allegedly collaborated with the Russian military.Rudneva admits that she is defending her dissertation at the Higher School of Economics, which cooperates with Skoltech, but claims that this is necessary to complete it work.At Skoltech itself, according to the educational institution‚Äôs website, Rudneva was listed as a research intern at the Krichever Center for Advanced Study from 2018 to 2022 and worked on a dissertation on the topic -Asymmetric vertex models and stochastic integrable processes.-The Swedish Migration Service refused to discuss individual cases. The country's security service said in an interview with Sveriges Radio that -their decisions are based on a comprehensive assessment of various factors- and that their task is -to ensure the protection of valuable technologies and research.-Rudneva appealed the deportation decision.-This research does not pose a threat. This is a fundamental science that studies exotic states of matter,- said Professor Emeritus Thors Hans Hansson in an interview with Sveriges Radio.

Also, -Radio Liberty- clarifies that the total number of those wounded in the war cannot be determined from these data, since it does not record cases when military personnel were returned to the front after treatment for minor injuries.For some military personnel who drank or took drugs, the diagnosis is -acute oral poisoning with an unknown substance,- -poisoning with unknown narcotic substances,- -acute poisoning with an alcohol-containing liquid.- -One day a lieutenant was brought to our hospital. Among them was Colonel Sergei Atroshchenko, commander of military unit 75387, 960th assault aviation regiment, who in Ukraine is called the man who gave orders to bomb the drama theater, maternity hospital, children's hospital and other objects in Mariupol. In 2023, the Ukrainian project Informnapal wrote that hackers hacked Atroshchenko's email and obtained lists of his subordinates and other information. -The number one killer of Mariupol residents has been identified. From the first weeks, we established that the planes that bombed Mariupol took off from the Primorsko-Akhtarsk airfield,- wrote Advisor to the Mayor of Mariupol Pyotr Andryushchenko in March 2023. Atroshchenko, as Inform Napalm found out, is a native of the Zhytomyr region. The project transferred the data of Atroshchenko and his subordinates to the appropriate structures for issuing a warrant from the International Criminal Court.On March 16, 2022, as a result of an airstrike within the walls of the Mariupol Drama Theater, up to several hundred people were killed, according to various estimates. Russia said 14 people were killed. Independent experts, Ukrainian authorities and witnesses claim that the strike was carried out by the Russian army. Russia claims that the theater was blown up from the inside by the Azov battalion. Previously, ASTRA conducted its investigation into the bombing of the theater, talking to more than 10 witnesses - some of them survived the airstrike and lost loved ones, some took refuge in the theater and left just a couple of hours before the disaster.

Description: A resident of Cherepovets was denied an abortion in all medical institutions in the city A 38-year-old resident of Cherepovets, Natalya (name changed), was denied an abortion in antenatal clinics in the city, as well as in private clinics in Cherepovets and Vologda. According to the woman, medical institutions in the region actually stopped providing this service without official explanation. -I live in the Cherepovets region, I have three children, my youngest daughter is three years old. I planned to go to work, but found out I was pregnant. I contacted a doctor at my place of residence, but I was told that he was not responsible for performing abortions. In a private clinic they did an ultrasound, set the period at eight weeks and explained that medical termination of pregnancy at this stage is no longer possible,- Natalya told the Rech newspaper. After this, the woman tried to sign up for an operation at the city maternity hospital, but was refused. -Yesterday was the last day we performed abortions. From today we have no right,- they told her over the phone.She received a similar answer in other antenatal clinics in the city. During a personal visit to one of the consultations, Natalia was explained that at the regional level a decision had been made to recommend that all women under 50 years of age continue pregnancy. However, she was not provided with any official documents, and she was not given a written refusal to have an abortion. Later, the woman turned to the official community of the maternity hospital on the social network VKontakte with a request to explain the reasons for the refusal. In response, she was informed that -termination of pregnancy is carried out only for medical reasons in a 24-hour hospital- and that this issue is regulated at the level of the government of the Vologda region. The couple considered the possibility of leaving the child, but came to the conclusion that they would not be able to provide for him morally and financially. -My husband already works three jobs. I spent ten years on maternity leave, and now I wanted to return to my professional activities,- explained Natalya. As a result, the woman had to go to a private clinic in the Yaroslavl region, where they agreed to carry out the operation without restrictions. The cost of the procedure was about nine thousand rubles.

Title: üñº A monument to Stalin will not be erected in Kaliningrad becaus...
Description: A monument to Stalin will not be erected in Kaliningrad because of his repressions and terror The head of the Kaliningrad administration, Elena Dyatlova, rejected the proposal of the local branch of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation to erect a monument to Joseph Stalin, citing historical documents condemning the cult of personality and political repression. In a response published on the party‚Äôs website, Dyatlova noted that the installation of monuments should not lead to conflicts in society, and recalled the 1956 resolution of the CPSU Central Committee -On overcoming the cult of personality and its consequences,- as well as the law -On the rehabilitation of victims of political repression.- She emphasized that the period from the 1930s to the early 1950s is recognized as the time of Stalinist repressions, and many years of terror and persecution of citizens of the USSR were condemned as incompatible with the idea of ‚Äã‚Äãlaw and justice.The Communist Party of the Russian Federation called Dyatlova‚Äôs position -a clear anti-Soviet position aimed at denigrating Soviet history and the great feat of the people.- The head of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation faction in the Legislative Assembly of the Kaliningrad Region, Maxim Bulanov, said that, in his opinion, the mayor is trying to whitewash his incompetence and inaction, which led to the deplorable state of the city. He emphasized that the party will not allow history to be rewritten and evaded responsibility.In recent years, monuments to Stalin have been erected regularly in Russia. These include busts and full-length monuments. In November-December 2024 alone, three monuments to Stalin were erected - in the Primorsky Territory, in North Ossetia and in the Vologda region. There are more than a hundred of them in total.Elena Dyatlova has held the post of mayor of Kaliningrad since November 2020 and at the same time heads the city branch of the United Russia party.

Description: Hamas handed over the bodies of four hostages to Israel. Among them are children who have become a symbol of the war in IsraelThe bodies of 33-year-old Shiri Bibas, her sons - five-year-old Ariel and two-year-old Kfir, as well as 83-year-old Oded Lifshitz were handed over to representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross in the south of the Gaza Strip, in the Khan Yunis area, reports The Jerusalem Post. He dedicated his life to helping others, including transporting sick Gazans to Israeli hospitals. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the day a -day of turmoil and sorrow- for the country and stressed that Israel was determined to prevent similar tragedies from happening in the future. After the transfer, the bodies were taken to the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Abu Kabir for official identification and determination of the cause. death.

Description: -Everything will be normal-: in Armenia, Russian security forces burst into a police station and demanded that activist Roman Shklover surrender to Russia The Barnaul activist, who was wanted in Russia on charges of -justifying terrorism,- received a call from the security department of the Yerevan metro on February 13.
